user_guide.title: User Guide
user_guide.main_text_area:
User Guide
For the "JSON Editor" program

This program is designed to edit JSON files both locally and remotely.

You can open a JSON file by selecting the "File" menu and then "Open". A graphical window will appear where you can choose the desired JSON file.
You can also open a folder with files and select a JSON file from the displayed file tree by using the "File" menu and then "Open Folder".

After opening a file, it will be displayed as a tree. You can modify it by clicking on a tree element and changing its values.
You can add new items to a list using the context menu (right-click) on the list item and selecting the desired action.

You can also select a different language for the application by choosing the "View" menu, then "Language", and selecting the desired translation.
You can add your own languages by dragging new JSON files with translated keys into the /resources/translate/ folder.

It is possible to establish a remote connection via SFTP. To do this, select the "Connection" menu, then "Configure". A window will open where you can enter the connection parameters.
After entering the data, click the "Save" button to save the parameters and check the connection authenticity.
Close the window and go to the "Connection" menu, then "Open Remote Folder".
If the connection is successful, the remote access folder will be displayed in the left panel.

Using the openssh-server package on a Debian server, you can configure SFTP connection. It is recommended to take the following restrictive measures and set specific parameters:

1. Create an SFTP user with limited shell access using the command:
   sudo adduser -shell /bin/false sftpuser
   This will create the sftpuser with shell access disabled.

2. Restrict user access only to the "files" directory by setting the owner and group for that directory:
   sudo chown sftpuser:sftpuser /var/sftp/files

3. Set the owner and group of /var/sftp as root and set the access permissions:
   sudo chown root:root /var/sftp
   sudo chmod 755 /var/sftp

4. Open the SSH configuration file in a text editor:
   sudo nano /etc/ssh/sshd_config

5. Add the following settings to the end of the file:
   Match User sftpuser
   	ForceCommand internal-sftp
   	PasswordAuthentication no
   	ChrootDirectory /var/sftp
   	PermitTunnel no
   	AllowAgentForwarding no
   	AllowTcpForwarding no
   	X11Forwarding no
   - The "Match User" directive specifies the username to which only SFTP configurations apply. In this case, it is "sftpuser".
   - The "ForceCommand internal-sftp" directive restricts user access only to SFTP and prohibits shell access.
   - The "PasswordAuthentication no" directive disables password authentication. It is recommended to use pre-installed SSH public key in the "~/.ssh/authorized_keys" file.
   - The "AllowAgentForwarding no", "AllowTcpForwarding no", and "X11Forwarding no" directives disable SSH agent forwarding, TCP forwarding, and X11 forwarding, respectively.

6. Restart the SSH service to apply the new settings:
   sudo systemctl restart ssh

It is important to note that these settings do not guarantee 100% secure connection. For maximum security, consider other factors beyond the scope of this guide.
